awd_titl_txt: Conjugate addition coupled to cationic cyclization: new methods for small molecule synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
With this Award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Alison Frontier of the University of Rochester, whose research program is focused on building small molecules with different three-dimensional architectures.  The spatial array of carbon, nitrogen and oxygen atoms of molecules is critical to the behavior of the molecules, specifically, their reactivity in different environments, and their ability to bind to other molecules. However, many natural and man-made molecules with potential uses as materials, catalysts, or pharmaceutical agents, are difficult to prepare using existing chemical protocols.  The research conducted by Professor Frontier and her students expands the range of three-dimensional molecules that can be assembled using chemical methods, and at the same time, develops chemical reactions that have not been previously described.  Through methods that form several new bonds in a single, controlled process, the group develops chemical strategies useful in a broad set of applications. Professor Frontier also continues to develop and maintain the "Not Voodoo" website, an educational resource.  The site is designed to help students demystify laboratory protocols and procedures. It serves hundreds of organic experimental chemists each day, from students just beginning independent research, to advanced students looking for more efficient synthetic methods. 

Synthetic chemists are constantly searching for versatile new methods for building densely functionalized molecules containing bridged, spirocyclic and fused ring systems, ideally with heteroatoms embedded in the scaffold of the three-dimensional molecules. The new methods Professor Frontier and her students are studying simplify the synthesis of targets with unusual, densely functionalized ring systems, including cycloheptane systems and nitrogen-rich heterocycles.  Novel pericyclic reactions are being developed in the context of reaction cascades that build complex ring systems from simple precursors, with the formation of up to three carbon-carbon or carbon-nitrogen bonds in one synthetic operation.  Given the stereochemical control imparted by these pericyclic processes, the work represents efforts to develop efficient, stereoselective reaction sequences while garnering a new understanding of the factors critical to successful multi-step processes with pericyclic components.  Students engaged in this work learn to devise synthetic strategies, analyze complex reaction outcomes ,and characterize small three-dimensional molecules. Professor Frontier's long-standing website project (Not Voodoo: Demystifying Synthetic Organic Chemistry) provides a resource for students learning laboratory techniques for the first time, and supporting more advanced students seeking to explore unfamiliar territory in their experimental work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Over the lifetime of this grant, we discovered new chemical transformations that rapidly construct different ring scaffolds comprised of carbon, oxygen, nitrogen and halide atoms arranged in novel arrays. With regard to Intellectual Merit, this work uncovered new types of chemical reactivity and new strategies for assembling small polycyclic molecules of novel structure, starting from simple precursors.  The carbon scaffolds of these molecules have unusual three-dimensional shapes, and contain reactive handles for attaching additional functional groups. Two transformations (?alkynyl Prins? coupling and ?halo-Nazarov? cyclization) occur in tandem during the assembly of the polycycles.  The work represents a new, highly efficient reaction combination, and some of the first examples of the halo-Nazarov class of reaction.  Overall, a carbonyl carbon is transformed into an sp3 carbon during the process (indicated by red dots in Scheme 1), so we describe it as a ?carbonyl pinch? strategy. The product halocyclopentenes can be functionalized further using cross-coupling strategies. We also carried out computational studies to help illuminate experimental results obtained, and have gained valuable insight into the thermochemistry and the mechanics of the stereoselectivity.

A second cascade cyclization that begins with linear precursors and generates two new rings (?double annulation?) was discovered during the grant period. These reactions generate polycyclic systems that contain oxygen and nitrogen atoms within the scaffold framework (Scheme 2).

In addition to the intellectual merit offered by the original research papers prepared during this grant period, four review articles were submitted and published over the course of the grant:  two reviewing reaction chemistry as it relates to synthetic strategy, and two invited articles for Accounts of Chemical Research, which describe our own work in two different areas of synthetic chemistry.  

The Broader Impacts of our work over the past grant period, we disclosed some innovative educational work carried out in the context of undergraduate teaching in the Journal of Chemical Education. The paper describes a unique course (The Chemistry of Poisons) developed by the PI at the University of Rochester.  The course content merges chemistry, biochemistry, social history and popular culture. The PI also maintains a website for beginning research students called Not Voodoo: Demystifying Synthetic Organic Chemistry. It is a resource to assist researchers at the earliest stage of their chemistry studies, as they are first confronted with an independent research project. These students, especially those studying at primarily undergraduate institutions and smaller universities, may not have a platoon of postdoctoral fellows nearby to give advice, impart wisdom, and teach them the ?tricks of the trade.? The site contains over 250 individual pages of information. During this grant period, we added new content, and performed significant maintenance/ housekeeping, engaging undergraduates in troubleshooting, optimizing navigation and improving visual presentation of the technical content.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/10/2022
Modified by: Alison J Frontier

    Alison Frontier
    Copyrighted
    Alison J Frontier
    Scheme 1
  • Alkynyl Prins Double Annulation
    Alison Frontier
